dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, when we talk about climate change and environmental impact, I think a lot of people immediately go to, like, cars or factories. But really, our food system, uh, is a massive player.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, when we talk about climate change and environmental impact, I think a lot of people immediately go to, like, cars or factories. But really, our food system, uh, is a massive player.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, it's not just a player; it's a huge contributor. We're talking, what, a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions? And it's the biggest cause of land-use change, biodiversity loss, drying up our rivers... it's a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, it's not just a player; it's a huge contributor. We're talking, what, a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions? And it's the biggest cause of land-use change, biodiversity loss, drying up our rivers... it's a lot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It accounts for about one-quarter of greenhouse-gas emissions and is the biggest cause of land-use change, biodiversity loss, and water extraction, leaving rivers dried out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty staggering when you think about it. And the big question, then, becomes, uh, can we actually feed a projected ten billion people by 2050, sustainably, with a healthy diet? Like, that's a *huge* challenge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty staggering when you think about it. And the big question, then, becomes, uh, can we actually feed a projected ten billion people by twenty fifty, sustainably, with a healthy diet? Like, that's a huge challenge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The big question is whether we can sustainably provide a healthy diet to a global population that is projected to reach ten billion by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And that's exactly what this EAT-Lancet Commission dug into. It was, what, like, thirty-seven scientists from sixteen different countries, including the author of this article, who really wanted to figure out this puzzle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And that's exactly what this E A T Lancet Commission dug into. It was, what, like, thirty-seven scientists from sixteen different countries, including the author of this article, who really wanted to figure out this puzzle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Two years ago, the EAT-Lancet Commission, comprising 37 scientists from 16 countries me included set out to provide an answer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they didn't just set out to give *an* answer. They kinda started by figuring out what a *bad* diet looked like and what its implications were for, um, global unsustainability. Which is a really interesting approach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they didn't just set out to give an answer. They kinda started by figuring out what a bad diet looked like and what its implications were for, um, global unsustainability. Which is a really interesting approach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We began by determining what a good diet for a healthy life should contain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And their findings, uh, were published in *The Lancet*, this medical journal. And apparently, they're the first to really identify these scientific targets for both our diets *and* the global food production system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And their findings, uh, were published in The Lancet, this medical journal. And apparently, they're the first to really identify these scientific targets for both our diets and the global food production system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Commission published its findings in January in the medical journal The Lancet. Our report identifies, for the first time, scientific targets for diets and the global food-production system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, I mean, the report has already generated, like, five thousand stories in the international media. But the author seems surprised it hasn't, you know, really "hit a nerve" more given its implications for everyone from farmers to consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, I mean, the report has already generated, like, five thousand stories in the international media. But the author seems surprised it hasn't, you know, really hit a nerve more given its implications for everyone from farmers to consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With more than 5,000 stories about the report already in the international media, its release clearly has hit a nerve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's kinda wild. Because their main conclusion, it's, um, it's not that feeding ten billion people sustainably is impossible. It's actually that it *is* possible, but it requires some pretty massive changes to our food system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's kinda wild. Because their main conclusion, it's, um, it's not that feeding ten billion people sustainably is impossible. It's actually that it is possible, but it requires some pretty massive changes to our food system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our main conclusion, supported by reams of peer-reviewed evidence, is that feeding ten billion people on a sustainable planet is possible. But doing so will require a transformation of the food system to address obesity, improve health, end forest loss, curb greenhouse-gas emissions, and protect the oceans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, what are those changes? What did they propose for, um, what we should be eating?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, what are those changes? What did they propose for, um, what we should be eating?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they've got this "planetary health diet." It's about 2,500 calories a day for an active person. And the big takeaway is significantly less red meat than most people are currently eating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they've got this planetary health diet. It's about two thousand, five hundred calories a day for an active person. And the big takeaway is significantly less red meat than most people are currently eating.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To achieve this, the Commission proposes a planetary health diet of 2,500 calories per day for an average global citizen leading an active life. ... We recommend that people eat significantly less red meat than they currently do in most parts of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so less red meat. [interrupts] Does that mean everyone has to go fully vegetarian or vegan?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so less red meat. Does that mean everyone has to go fully vegetarian or vegan?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not necessarily, no. They suggest, like, a typical week could include a hamburger, maybe a couple of chicken dishes, one or two fish meals, but then the *rest* would be plant-based. So, it's not, um, exclusively vegan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not necessarily, no. They suggest, like, a typical week could include a hamburger, maybe a couple of chicken dishes, one or two fish meals, but then the rest would be plant-based. So, it's not, um, exclusively vegan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A typical weekly meal plan under our proposal might include a hamburger, a couple of chicken dishes, and one or two fish meals, with the others being plant-based.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Interesting. So, like, it's more about balance and shifting the *proportion* of what we eat. But, you know, just changing our diet, that's not gonna magically fix everything, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Interesting. So, like, it's more about balance and shifting the proportion of what we eat. But, you know, just changing our diet, that's not gonna magically fix everything, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is important to recognize that shifting to the planetary health diet will not in itself lead to sustainable production. We also need to improve how we produce what we eat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, definitely not. The report stresses that changing our diet, like, it's only one piece of the puzzle. We also have to fundamentally change *how* we produce our food. You know, address food waste, move to more efficient systems...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely not. The report stresses that changing our diet, like, it's only one piece of the puzzle. We also have to fundamentally change how we produce our food. You know, address food waste, move to more efficient systems...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It needs to halve the amount of food waste by 2050. It must move to more efficient and sustainable production systems and invest more in healthier crops.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it's not just about what's on our plate, but, like, the whole farm-to-fork journey. And I think the goal here isn't to be prescriptive for every single culture or region.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it's not just about what's on our plate, but, like, the whole farm-to-fork journey. And I think the goal here isn't to be prescriptive for every single culture or region.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We went to great lengths to stress that this diet is flexible and can be adapted to different cultures and different produce, whether Asian, European, African, or those of the Americas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. It's more about, um, sparking a global conversation among all stakeholders. Farmers, consumers, food companies. What are we going to be eating, and how are we going to produce it, in the next ten, twenty, thirty years?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. It's more about, um, sparking a global conversation among all stakeholders. Farmers, consumers, food companies. What are we going to be eating, and how are we going to produce it, in the next ten, twenty, thirty years?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, we want the report to start a discussion among all stakeholders from farmers to consumers about what we will be eating, and how we produce it, ten, 20, and 30 years from now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Because if we don't, uh, our current food system could really harm us and the planet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because if we don't, uh, our current food system could really harm us and the planet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If we can do that, our food system can benefit, rather than harm, our own health and that of the planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a wake-up call, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a wake-up call, for sure.
